resource.chars: Which Love wanted me to feel.
Do not understand by this that my heart might be able,
One day, to distance itself,
However much I have to suffer
In great pain and great torment.
This makes me see, if ever I knew anything about all this,
That the body can be pulled easily
Towards wherever it pleases the heart.
Therefore I am caught, without a doubt,
For, without leaving anything behind,
Love has seized everything according to his pleasure—
Heart, members, body, intellect.
And certainly, in order to do his bidding,
I want to offer him my body and heart
For as long as I am liberated
By my lady, to whom I have handed myself over.
But when I am able to know for certain
That no treasure, no wealth,
However much I might be able to give,
Would not be able to ransom me,
Or loosen the bonds in any way—
Those where I have been taken as hers—
Of she whom I must call my lady,
Except for loyally loving
And courageously serving,
For this reason, in order to merit forgiveness,
So that I might one day be delivered.
Know that as long as I have to live,
Without any reservations at all,
If I have recklessly placed
In honor and without shame,
My heart, body, intellect and understanding
—Without reserving anything—
Into serving my very sweet lady,
It is certainly right that I am imprisoned,
For I was born under a fortunate star,
When it was written into my destiny
That I would devote my attention to serving
Such a sweet creature
—In whom there might be so much beauty enclosed—
As my lady, who is a rose
In both intellect and beauty,
Because of which I must, it seems to me,
Love, serve and honor her.
Alas! It can stay this way too long,
However much serving I do,
Before I obtain assistance or pardon
From my lady, from the sickness
That I feel, full of amorous fury,
And because of which, in her prison, night and day,
I languish, sick, with no reprieve.
For how would she rescue me,
The sweet lady, when she never received
Any news through me,
For she held me so tight in her chains?
For I have not yet been so bold;
I am taken prisoner, and fearful that
My heart, which appears to be open,
Has not been revealed to her.
Certainly, this would be too difficult to do!
And because I can I might well suffer
Before being treated this way,
If it is not known by my lady,
For who without anything easy
Would be able to relieve my suffering?
Whatever might happen afterwards,
I want her to perceive or notice,
If this pleases her, in what way
I have undertaken to serve her with my heart.
But I do not see how
More nobly or more completely
I would be able to reveal my heart
To the sweet and wise lady
If it is not in singing, and because of this,
With as loyal a heart as I must have,
I sing, letting myself go with my desire:
I gave myself to you, without fear,
My lady, in such a way that
I placed all of my efforts in you,
Without ever ceasing
In all of the days of my life.
Ah! Lady adorned in all virtues,
May it please the great nobility
Which resides in your body,
And the sweetness and the generosity
Which are always within you,
May they wish to move your heart
So that I am not, at any cost,
Taken away by you, but may you rather
Wish to take me
And to consider my service,
So that if your sweet heart considers
If through my loyal love,
I should be called your lover,
And if the suffering and pain
Which weighs upon my heart
—For I have pain now and used to have some—
Should be favorably received.
And, however much I have served,
I must not have failed to deserve that
One grant me
The mercy for which I must implore you so much.
May it please you, my lady, at least
To lighten my suffering,
That I find a sweet appearance in you,
And that I see, without fear, that I might
Confirm the hope in my heart
To obtain what I wish for:
This is to be received as a lover.
If my misfortune is such,
Lady, as long as God does not consent
That sweetness and noble pity
Flee so far away from you
That I might find opposition
In my situation of need [?],
Truly, certainly, at that hour
Bad fortune was showered upon me
When I looked at your sweet face,
My lady, if you, in whom I have placed
All of my attention and solicitude,
Desired to show me a welcome
Thanks to which, reasonably,
The good hope that must remain in me
—And through which I expect relief from you —
Would wane, alas, I would just as well hang myself!
For what evil could befall me as much as
Losing your assistance?
Alas, lady, I would be so afflicted
If I lost your sweet assistance!
For certainly, if it were lost to me,
It is my life that would be lacking!
But how could it happen
That you not retain me,
For I am, lady, joined to you
As true love joined me to you.
And you know the purity [of love?]!
Certainly it would be a great trial
And it would be very difficult for me to believe,
For, my lady, nothing comforts me so much
As the fact that when I saw your sweet face,
When my heart was ravished by love,
It seemed to be above all others
Gracious, worthy of pity, and sweet.
For it did not seem in any way,
